level.heading: Abatement of real property taxes for Howard Town Center.

level.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, the tax imposed by Chapter 8 of this title on the real property described as Lots 930 and 933, Square 2877, and any improvements thereon, owned by Howard University and developed by Howard Town Center Developer, LLC, shall be abated for 10 real property tax years in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.
The abatement provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall:
Commence with the tax year in which the final certificate of occupancy is issued to the last property developed on the site, but in no case before October 1, 2015.
Be in the amount of $800,000 per year, not to exceed $8 million in the aggregate over 10 years.
To receive the abatement provided for in subsection (a) of this section:
The development of the real property shall:
Be a mixed-use development;
Comply with § 2-219.03 and § 2-218.46;
Require that at least 51% of construction hours are completed by District residents;
Require that at least 51% of the permanent jobs in the development are filled by District residents; and
Reserve all the apprenticeships in the development project for District residents; and
The Mayor shall certify to the Office of Tax and Revenue that the development project has met each of the conditions set forth in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

level.heading: Effect of Amendments
level.text: The 2013 amendment by D.C. Law 20-61 substituted "October 1, 2015" and a closing period for "October 1, 2014; and" in (b)(1); and in (b)(2), substituted "$800,000" for "$1.1 million" and "$8 million" for "$11 million".

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 19-257
level.text: Law 19-257, the "Howard Town Center Real Property Tax Abatement Act of 2012," was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 19-443. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on Dec. 4, 2012, and Dec. 18, 2012, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on Jan. 14, 2013, it was assigned Act No. 19-593 and transmitted to Congress for its review. D.C. Law 19-257 became effective on Apr. 20, 2013.
